gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Land Use Systems of the World

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: Version 1.1 of a thematic grid of Land Use Systems (LUS) and its attributes for East Europe & Central Asia with a spatial resolution of 5 arc minutes or 0.083333 decimal degrees. This dataset is developed in the framework of the LADA project (Land degradation Assessment in Drylands) by the Land Tenure and Management Unit of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations and is copyright of FAO/UNEP GEF. The LUS map implementation is based on a innovative methodology combining more than 10 global datasets. Due to the map generation method, the quality of the map can never be uniform. The overall quality of the map depends heavily on the individual quality of the data for the different countries.

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: The general purpose of the map is to describe the Land Use Systems of the world.

gmd:supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString: The map shows the Land Use systems units on a raster with a resolution of 5 minutes, while its attributes table includes: land use systems, ecosystems, crops, crop groups, irrigated areas, thermal climate, LGP, soils, terrain, slope, population density and infant mortality rate.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Land Use Systems of the World
Using cereal grain winter cover crops to reduce groundwater nitrate contamination

gmd:name.gco:CharacterString: Distribution page for global land use data

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Distribution page for global land use data

gmd19157:description.gco:CharacterString: Reclassification of 233 categories (photointerpretation enables a very detailed legend) of the original MCSC into 12 categories. The choice of the classification legend is based on a simplification of MCSC product to a ground truth of 12 categories (using spectral features and biological consistency of the legend categories as main criteria)

Land Cover Map of Catalonia MCSC (3rd Edition, raster format) (Mapa de Cobertes del sòl de Catalunya. 3ª Edició, model ràster) (2005-2007). Obtained from photointerpretation of 0.5 m spatial resolution ortophotographies. 233 land cover categories legend. 20m pixel size. Centre de Recerca Ecològica i Aplicacions Forestals CREAF (2007)

Obtain a MCSC reclassified raster file with NODATA on the border pixels between categories. The aim of this step is to assure homogeneous training areas and avoid introducing the mixtures that characterize the transition between landcover categories.
Original MCSC (raster format) reclassified into 12 categories (result of the MCSC_reclassification process step)
Vectorize the MCSC reclassified raster file (result of the MCSC_reclassification process step)

Combination of the vectorized MCSC with a 1km grid. This partition is applied to fragment larger polygons into several smaller polygons, with the aim of selecting a % of its surface for posterior sampling purposes (training areas, test areas, validation areas subsamples). Thus, only the larger polygons are fragmentated.
MSCS vector (result of the Vectorize_MCSC_reclass process step)

Finally, a stratified subsampling using a R syntax randomly assigns each gridded MCSC polygon values 1 to 3. Value 1 are training polygons (50% of the area), value 2 are test polygons (25% of the area) and value 3 are validation polygons (25% of the area). Accordingly, this layer is split into three polygon layers. One of each is combined with the MCSC reclassified raster file with NODATA on the border pixels (MCSC_reclass_buffer source) to generate three raster files with (training pixels, test pixels and validation pixels, with sources id's equal to MCSC_train_12cat, MCSC_test_12cat, MCSC_test_test_12cat). Each of these raster subsamples contain all the categories included on the legend (12 categories).
Combination of the vectorized MCSC with a 1km grid (result of the OnekmGrid_MCSC_Vector process step)
MCSC reclassified raster file with NODATA on the border pixels (result of the Buffer_MCSC_reclass process step)

gmd:attributeDescription.gco:RecordType: This layer is the error model validation layer, i.e. a binomial layer representing coincidence between the values predicted by the logistic regression model and the observed values (either correct/incorrect pixels).

gmd19157:description.gco:CharacterString: A selection in the LC_prob_source (is the same layer than LC_prob ID coverageDescription) layer applying the success/failure threshold to respectively above or equal 50% values and below 50% values generates a binomial layer of correctly classified/incorrectly classified pixels (this is to say predicted correct/incorrect pixels by the logistic regression model).

The hybrid classification product (id="LC_source") is crossed with the third subsample of the ground truth (25% of the MCSC: validation areas, named test-test) in order to derive another layer with coinciding categories between the validation areas (ground truth) and the assigned categories in the classification product (landcover map). A reclassified binomial layers assigns value 1 to pixels in which the category coincides (correctly classified pixels) and 0 to pixels in which the category does not coincide (incorrectly classified pixels). This layer represents observed correct/incorrect pixels.

The binomial layer obtained (predicted correct/incorrect pixels according to the logistic regression model) is crossed with the observed correct/incorrect pixels layer. In the resulting layer, the focus is on coincidence between predicted by the logistic regression model and observed either correct/incorrect pixels (this means that both combinations are fine: 1-1 and 0-0 in this overlaying). This layer is the validation layer. (1 999 080 number of pixels 1-1 coincident/424 893 number of pixels 0-0 coincidences, and 0-1/1-0 disagreements!. Taking into account that this validation is carried out in the 25% of the surface of the ground truth area -only where the validation subsample is available i.e. total of 2 848 866 pixels, in the end this implies a 85.08% coincidence -either in correct or incorrect pixels-)

gmd:attributeDescription.gco:RecordType: Average success probability for the statistical cluster obtained from linear regression model (object level mean average success probability expressed in %)

gmd19157:description.gco:CharacterString: The IsoMM (Isodata product) is the layer from which the polygons are delimited (polygons=statistical cluster). From these polygons, the weighed by area average values of the independent variables layers (F, F2, F3, R, R2, R3, H, I, P, Q) and the dependent layer (for the testing areas subsample of the MCSC boundaries of the IsoMM -Isodata product-), mean values of the pixels inside the polygons: this is to say mean of the probability of success % obtained at pixel level based on observed values for the test subsample)

Linear regression model fitting in SPSS software: selection of the best model based on higher adjusted determination coeficient and parsimony principle. The selected model only uses F as independent variable (Adjusted determination coeficient=0.943) $$ check uncertML/Thesaurus discussion July2013

Validation of the linear regression model by replicating the process using as dependent variable the mean probability of success in the validation subsample (this is to say, the 25% test_test areas: MCSC_test_test_12cat). The obtained goodness of fit statistic Adjusted determination coeficient values is similar (0.931). Application of both models and correlation between predicted mean probability of successes (%) between both models' predictions: very similar models, and very close to 1 correlations

Application of the Linear regression model in the algebra calculator in MiraMon software: generation of the mean probability of success at polygon level. ($$$ Discovered issue: 23July: values of the RegLin model should be between 0-1? but applying the model, the values obtained are higher than 1 in 1942355 pixels!!)

gmd19157:statement.gco:CharacterString: The obtention of the hybrid classification product (ID="LC" in coverageDescription) is explained on the next processStep (****). Moreover, see the reports explaing the traces: ConfMat_test_trace, RegLog_trace, RegLin_trace for other coverageDescription's lineage.

gmd19157:description.gco:CharacterString: Unsupervised classification (Isodata algorithm) of 47 standardized bands (6dates x6bands=36 landsat bands, 1 slope map, 6 NDVIs, 4 topoclimatic variables)

Landsat-5 Thematic Mapper (path 197, row 31) 6 dates multitemporal set (2005-2007), 6 optical bands (30 m spatial resolution). thermal band discarded due to low spatial resolution (120m) after geometric correctected

Geometric (Palà and Pons 1995) and radiometric corrections (Pons and Solé-Sugrañes 1994) using ASTER DEM (ERSDAC 2009), applying clouds, cloud shadows, sea and snow cover masks. Resampling to 20 m spatial resolution.Transformation to calculate NDVI (Spectral vegetation index -Rouse et al. 1973-) for each date. Bands standardization (Spiegel 1991) to avoid difference of measurement units among the bands to be introduced in the classification process.

Slope map derived from DTM based on PNOA at 5 m spatial resolution using 8 neighbours method and adapted to the 20 m resampled bands (median resolution change). This band is intended to account for the relief in terraces, abrupt or vertical slopes. Standardization of the slope maps to avoid difference of measurement units among the bands to be introduced in the classification process.

Topoclimatic variables calculated from the historical series of the Digital Climatic Atlas of Catalonia (minimum temperature of the average minimum temperature of the three coldest months, maximum temperature of the average maximum temperature of the three hotest months, minimum limiting precipitation of the three months with less precipitation, minimum solar radiation of the three months with less solar radiation). Standardization.
Supervised classification introducing the training areas (subsample of the 50% of the MCSC: MCSC_train_12cat). Fidelity and representatitvity parameters set to 0.
IsoMM process result in 957 statistical clusters (result of the IsoMM_process process step)

gvq:knownProblem.gco:CharacterString: Legend choice is subjective. Some of the original 233 categories have been reclassified as nodata. In the end the % of the MCSC that has been used (with buffering) is 41.38% of the study area. Difficulties in fitting the photointerpretation product legend with a suitable spectral features legend.

gvq:workAround.gco:CharacterString: Use of the Habitats Maps of Catalonia -available online from the regional government web- to compare the categories between them and reject the most mixed ones when doubtful.

gvq:knownProblem.gco:CharacterString: The classification steps (both unsupervised and supervised classification steps) are affected by the selection of the multitemporal landsat scenes. In order to avoid shadows to minimize radiometric corrections loss of pixels, we have not selected scenes from November to March, and the avoidance of this period is crucial in the correct classification or distinction of broadleaved tree species and other categories. Nonetheless, the main problem in classification in Mediterranean areas is the diversity and presence of mixed forests and landcovers.

gvq:workAround.gco:CharacterString: Include autumn-winter scenes in the classification to better discriminate coniferous/deciduous species, but the most problematic is to distinguish within deciduous species (other scenes during the spring-summer period should be included, when some species have already grown leaves whether others have not yet).Consider NDVI discrimination criteria between the most problematic categories is not useful in this case because most forest landcovers are mixed forests and eventhough the broadleaved loose their leaves, other holm oaks are underneath and introduce confusion in the hybrid classification process.

gvq:knownProblem.gco:CharacterString: Some methodological constraints can be defined.

gvq:workAround.gco:CharacterString: First of all be careful with legend categories (legend is always a subjective choice). The legend chosen is suited to the objectives of the present study. However, it might be unsufficient for precise ecological or botanical studies at local scales. Classification methods differ in results at pixel level, both in categories assignment and associated uncertainty. Moreover, be careful with areas with high uncertainty (checking them in the provided probabilistic maps). Spatial and temporal resolution constraint the potential usage of the product).

gvq:userComment.gvq:comment: Metadata record is of very good quality.

gvq:rating.gvq:justification: Metadata provides quality information which helps to evaluate dataset's fitness for use.

gvq:usage.gvq:usageDescription: I used this dataset for classification of vegetation in the Warwickshire area, UK, in 2012.

gvq:userComment.gvq:comment: Overall, the dataset provides good spatial and temporal coverage.
The metadata records is beyond the expectation allowing for error traceability. Very detailed quality information.

gvq:rating.gvq:justification: The data can be recommended for land cover research. The metadata records is beyond the expectation allowing for error traceability.

gvq:userComment.gvq:comment: The dataset was used for classification of vegetation cover in the UK, in 2011 - 2013. Extremely detailed metadata record.

gvq:rating.gvq:justification: The metadata records was beyond my expectation.

gvq:userComment.gvq:comment: I used this dataset for observation of UK land use between 2011 and 2012. The data is of very high quality. Metadata record provides quality information.

gvq:rating.gvq:justification: The dataset and metadata record are of very good quality.

gvq:userComment.gvq:comment: The dataset was used to monitor changes in land cover in Germany between 2009 and 2013. We would highly recommend this dataset for land use applications.

gvq:rating.gvq:justification: The dataset is highly recommended for land cover research.

gvq:userComment.gvq:comment: I used this dataset for monitoring changes in vegetation cover in the UK between May 2010 and June 2011. The data is of very high quality and quality information is available.

gvq:rating.gvq:justification: The data is of very high quality and quality information is available.

gvq:userComment.gvq:comment: The dataset was used for classification of land cover in Spain. The dataset and metadata record are of very high quality. Quality information is available.
We used this dataset to classify vegetation cover in Turkey for the year 2012. The dataset provides very good spatial and temporal coverage.
Our university used this dataset to monitor changes in the agricultural land use in Spain between 2009 and 2011. We would highly recommend this dataset for landcover research.

gvq:rating.gvq:justification: Metadata record is extremely good. Quality and lineage information is available.
